questions.text: Mixing biomedical waste with different constituents before disposal to reduce its toxicities is known as _______.
questions.solution:
Inertization is the process of mixing the biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity in the waste and to reduce the contamination of ground water.
It is most commonly used for incineration ash with high metal content

The typical composition of the mixture is

  • 65% pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% cement
  • 15% lime
  • Water

Other options:

  • Incineration is a waste management method that involves the controlled burning of waste materials at high temperatures. It is often used for the disposal of various types of waste, including biomedical waste. Incineration is effective in reducing the volume of waste and destroying potentially infectious or hazardous materials through the application of high heat.
  • Compacting is a waste management technique that involves reducing the volume of waste by compressing it. This is typically done using specialized machinery or compactors. Compacting can make waste easier to transport and store, but it does not inherently reduce the toxicity of the waste.

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient who had the surgery 3 months back presents with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. On fundoscopy, there is a honeycomb appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and a honeycomb appearance on fundoscopy is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows loss of foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  honeycomb appearance. In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B- Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C- Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D- Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It is indicated when the patient is symptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following Vitamins is not required in the TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine is not required in the TCA cycle.

Vitamins, in the form of their respective coenzymes, are required for the proper functioning of the TCA cycle.

The following vitamins are needed in the TCA cycle:

  • Thiamine as TPP, for decarboxylation in the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reaction
  • Riboflavin as FAD and FMN, for succinate dehydrogenase
  • Niacin as NAD and NADH, for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase
  • Pantothenic acid as a part of Coenzyme A helps to form acetyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA.

questions.text: A 35-year-old rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, tremors, and vomiting. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The rice farmer presents with features of acute encephalitis and non-specific features like fever, cough, and diarrhea, and is most likely suspected to have Japanese encephalitis. The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquito due to unspotted wings and hunched back, which is a vector of Japanese encephalitis. 

Culex mosquitoes:

They are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

In the larval stage, they are suspended with heads downwards at an angle, a siphon tube is present, and there is an absence of palmate hairs. They lay the eggs in clusters, and adult mosquitoes have their wings unspotted with hunched back.

Various mosquito larvae are shown in the image below. Siphon tube is present in Aedes and Culex, whereas, it is absent in Anopheles.

 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds. Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs. Ultra-low-volume fogging is a method of insecticide application where a small volume (<500 ml/hectare) of liquid insecticide is applied to provide maximum killing of disease vectors.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

questions.text: A young man was started on the drug which is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of platelets after percutaneous coronary intervention. Identify this drug.
questions.solution:
Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of the platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. It reduces the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events in such patients. 

Side effects include bleeding and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura in rare cases. Administration of prasugrel with an anticoagulant or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug is avoided as it may increase the risk of bleeding. Contraindicated in patients above 75 years of age and those with a history of cerebrovascular disease.

Other options:

Option A: Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Tirofiban acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. It has a short duration of action and is used for the management of patients with non–non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome.

Option C: Eptifibatide acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: The body of a missing person was found tied to a boat. During the autopsy, you notice the presence of the following organism in his brain tissue. Which of the following is not a possible cause for this finding?
questions.solution:

Diatoms are microscopic unicellular or colonial algae present in water. As the diatoms are found in both seawater and freshwater, their presence cannot differentiate between freshwater and seawater drowning.

The presence of diatoms in the brain tissue is suggestive of antemortem drowning, as only a living person can transport diatoms from the lungs to the viscera via circulation.

questions.text: Calculate hepatic clearance of a drug with hepatic blood flow of 2000 mL/min and hepatic extraction ratio of 0.5.
questions.solution:
The hepatic clearance is 1000 mL/min.

Clearance of a drug by an organ is the difference between the rate of presentation of the drug to the organ and the rate of exit of the drug from the organ. It is calculated by the equation:

CLorgan = Q x (CA-CV/CA)

where,

CLorgan =Clearance of the drug by the organ

Q = Blood flow to the organ

CA = Arterial drug concentration

CV = Venous drug concentration.

Extraction ratio (E) is the fraction of the drug that is removed from the blood by the eliminating organ. CA is the concentration of drug presented to the organ and CA-CV is the drug removed by the organ, hence,

Extraction ratio (E) = CA-CV/CA

Therefore, the clearance of the drug by the organ can be simply written as,

CLorgan = Q x E

In the question, it is given that the hepatic blood flow is 2000 mL/min and Hepatic extraction ratio is 0.5.

Substituting the values in the above equation, 

CLorgan = 2000 X 0.5

= 1000 mL/min

questions.text: Which of the following is a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide?
questions.solution:
Permethrin is a synthetic pyrethroid. Pyrethroids are synthetic insecticides, which are derived from naturally occurring pyrethrins. Pyrethroids modify the sodium channels in neuronal membranes and thereby disrupt the electrical signalling in the nervous system. 

Permethrin is effective in killing or repelling insects and is often used in products like insect repellent sprays, creams, and treated clothing for personal protection against insect bites.

Other options:

  • Propoxur is not a synthetic pyrethroid insecticide. It is a carbamate insecticide used for pest control.
  • Parathion is not a pyrethroid insecticide either. It is an organophosphorus insecticide, which works differently from pyrethroids.
  • Pyrolan is not a commonly known insecticide and is not a synthetic pyrethroid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Random error is a type of error in epidemiological studies that is difficult to eliminate and it is different from bias. Random error is when a value of the sample measurement diverges - due to chance alone - from that of the true population value, whereas bias comes under the category of systematic errors.

Other options:

  • Recall or Memory Bias: This occurs when there is differential recall of exposure or outcome information between cases and controls, leading to an over- or underestimation of the true association.
  • Confounding: Confounding occurs when an extraneous variable is associated with both the exposure and the outcome and can distort the true relationship between them.
  • Selection Bias: Selection bias occurs when there is a systematic difference between the cases and controls in terms of how they are selected or recruited into the study, leading to a biased estimate of the association between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: The non-communicable disease (NCD)  clinic at the district hospital screens people above the age of 50 years with positive family history for diabetes.  What type of screening is this?
questions.solution:
The non-communicable disease/ NCD clinic at the district hospital screening people above the age of 50 years for diabetes is a type of high-risk screening. 

Screening is searching or testing for diseases or defects that are not evident in apparently healthy individuals. 

High-risk or selective screening is screening applied selectively to high-risk groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research. For example, screening the other members in families of patients with diabetes or hypertension. It is an effective and economical method of screening.  

Other options:

Option A: Mass screening is the screening of a population or a sub-group of the population for a disease irrespective of the particular risk an individual may run of contracting the disease in question.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests (instead of carrying out separate screening tests for a single disease) to a large number of people in the form of health questionnaires, clinical examinations, and investigations. 

Option C: Prospective screening is screening people for the benefit of others. For example, screening immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis to protect the home population from the disease.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe breathlessness with wheezing. Her peak expiratory flow rate is reduced significantly. Which of the following enzymes has an important role in the pathogenesis of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute exacerbation of asthma in which 5-lipoxygenase enzyme plays an important role.

Acute exacerbation of asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction due to chemicals mediators such as leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4 etc.) which are produced from the breakdown of arachidonic acid by 5-lipoxygenase via the lipoxygenase pathway. 

The leukotrienes are a family of conjugated trienes formed from eicosanoic acids in leukocytes, mastocytoma cells, platelets, and macrophages by the lipoxygenase (LOX) pathway. They are potent constrictors of the bronchial airway musculature.

These leukotrienes together with leukotriene B4 also cause increased vascular permeability and activation and attraction of leukocytes and are involved in many inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions, such as asthma.

Leukotrienes are also vasoactive, and 5-lipoxygenase is found in arterial walls.

Note: 

Lipoxins are a family of conjugated tetraenes also arising in leukocytes. They are formed by the combined action of more than one lipoxygenase.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy is brought to the doctor because his family found him dressed as a woman. He says that he derives sexual pleasure from this act. However, he has no wish to undergo sex-change surgery. What is this type of perversion called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of fetishistic transvestism.

It is a paraphilia characterized by recurrent sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges, or behavior involving the wearing of clothes of the opposite sex and appearing as a member of the opposite sex. It is also called transvestic fetishism. It is usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes.

Fetishistic transvestism is a paraphilia whereas transvestism is a gender identity disorder. There is no hormonal/genital abnormality in fetishistic transvestism.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Diet deficient in vitamin C or ascorbic acid, can lead to microcytic-hypochromic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. Ascorbic acid cannot be synthesized in human beings because of the absence of L-gulonolactone oxidase. Gooseberries and citrus fruits are rich sources of vitamin C. 

It is mainly required for hydroxylation reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. The active form of vitamin C is ascorbic acid.

Iron absorption is enhanced by vitamin C. It reduces the ferric iron to its ferrous form, thereby helping in the process of absorption of dietary iron from the intestine.

Vitamin C deficiency causes

  • Decreased hydroxylation of proline and lysine, which results in defective collagen synthesis and bleeding manifestations.
  • Decreased absorption of iron leading to microcytic-hypochromic anemia

A deficiency state of vitamin C results in scurvy. Clinical features are:

  • Loose and spongy gums along with loose teeth
  • Swollen joints
  • Hemorrhages
  • Bleeding into the skin - ecchymosis, purpura, petechiae
  • Bone changes
  • Microcytic anemia (due to decreased absorption of iron from the intestine)
  • Scorbutic rosary - sharp, tender beading at the costochondral junctions.

Other options:

Option A- Glutathione is present in glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme acts as an antioxidant. It helps in the destruction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.

Option B- β-carotene is provitamin A, found in plants. It helps in the formation of retinaldehyde which is utilized in vision, and retinoic acid which plays a role in the control of gene expression.

Option D- Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes like carboxypeptidases, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, the cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, etc. Chronic zinc deficiency can cause dwarfism, hypogonadism, dermatitis, and T-cell immunodeficiency. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormalities in zinc absorption.

questions.text: An infant was brought with failure to thrive. On examination, the infant appears floppy with an enlarged tongue, hypotonia, skeletal muscle weakness, and hepatomegaly. The chest X-ray is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and urine glucose tetrasaccharide. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the above-given clinical scenario and the radiograph showing cardiomegaly, Pompe's disease is the most likely diagnosis.

Pompe's disease (Type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiencyleading to lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells. It can appear within weeks or months after birth (infantile Pompe disease) or may appear late in juvenile, childhood, or adulthood disease (late-onset Pompe disease).

The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, macroglossia, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly. 

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Urine glucose tetrasaccharide, a glycogen breakdown metabolite, is a reliable biomarker for disease severity and treatment response.

Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen. It is diagnosed by detecting the decreased activity of the enzyme, α-1,4-glucosidase in the dried blood spots, leukocytes, blood mononuclear cells, muscle, or cultured skin fibroblasts.

Other options:

Option A: Von Gierke disease occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. Patients present commonly in 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C: McArdle disease occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D: Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases uric acid in urine?
questions.solution:
Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acid.

Probenecid is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. The drug acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubules that are involved in uric acid reabsorption. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia.

Probenecid increases urinary urate levels. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation. Probenecid should not be used in gouty patients with nephrolithiasis or with overproduction of uric acid.

Probenecid inhibits penicillin's urinary excretion, prolonging penicillin action by enhancing and sustaining their blood levels. It inhibits the urinary excretion of other drugs such as cephalosporins, sulfonamides, methotrexate, and indomethacin. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of the drug.

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall it reduces the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol acts by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

questions.text: A patient with chronic angina was prescribed a drug which acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart. Which among the following could be the prescribed drug?
questions.solution:
Ranolazine acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart.

Mechanism of action- Late sodium current (INa) facilitates entry of calcium via the sodium-calcium exchanger. Inhibition of INa, therefore, reduces the intracellular calcium concentration which in turn reduces the diastolic tension, cardiac contractility and work.

At higher doses, it may also modify the fatty acid oxidation, which improves the efficiency of cardiac oxygen utilization.

It is used in the prophylaxis of angina.

questions.text: An HIV-positive female patient presents with acute rhinitis. On examination, a greyish membrane is seen in the nasal mucosa.  Exploration of the maxillary sinus reveals a fungus ball containing semisolid blackish material. Histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of aspergillosis. 

Aspergillus shows narrow, septate hyphae with typical dichotomous branching at acute angles (45°) on microscopy.

Clinical features of aspergillosis include acute/ subacute rhinitis or sinusitis. As given in the question stem, on examination black or greyish membrane would be seen in the nasal mucosa, and exploration of maxillary sinus would show a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material. The organisms can be seen on special staining for fungus.

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs

The usual causative organisms are Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus fumigatus or Aspergillus flavus, which invade nasal tissues in any immunocompetent host.

Surgical debridement of the involved tissues and antifungal drugs, e.g. Amphotericin B. Repeated irrigation of the involved area with application of 1% solution of gentian violet is also useful.

Other options:

Option A: Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.  It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised individuals. Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus. The local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge is typically seen in invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It presents as nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: Among the following options, disease elimination can be helped the most by ____.
questions.solution:
Disease elimination can be helped the most by herd immunity. 

When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease. Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization for diseases like polio, diphtheria, and measles, goes a long way in helping the elimination of disease. A large section of the population would be immune to disease through herd immunity.

questions.text: You were asked to perform fundoscopy in a patient diagnosed with hypertensive retinopathy. You notice arteriovenous nicking with tapering of veins on either side of the crossings on fundoscopic examination. This sign is known as _______
questions.solution:
Tapering of veins on either side of the crossings is known as the Gunn sign, which is seen on fundoscopy in a patient with hypertensive retinopathy.

Arteriovenous nicking is the hallmark of hypertensive retinopathy. It occurs where the arteriole crosses and compresses the vein, as the vessels share a common adventitious sheath.

These changes are also known as A-V crossing changes and they include:

  • Salu’s sign is the deflection of veins at the arteriovenous crossings.
  • Bonnet sign is the banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings, and
  • Gunn sign is the tapering of veins on either side of the crossings.

 

Grading of Hypertensive Retinopathy:

Grade 1: Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing

Grade 2: Focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping. Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls as a copper wiring can be seen.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus dot/blot/flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton wool spots. Chronic retinal edema results in the deposition of hard exudates around the fovea as a macular star. 

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. It is a marker of malignant hypertension

questions.text: The function of which of the following factors is not screened by the partial thromboplastin time assay?
questions.solution:
The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic pathway. As factor VII is only a part of the extrinsic pathway, it cannot be assessed by this test.

The factors assessed by the PTT assay are XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, and II and fibrinogen.

In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negatively charged particles (e.g., ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defective
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defective type 2 pneumocytes which produce lung surfactants.

Respiratory distress syndrome is a condition seen in premature infants due to a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant in an immature lung.

Pulmonary surfactants are made up of a mixture of lipids, phospholipids, and proteins. The surfactants decrease alveolar surface tension thereby facilitating expansion and preventing atelectasis. In a preterm infant, there is a decrease in both the quantity and quality of the surfactant.

The primary alveoli develop and the production of the surfactant begins by weeks 20-24. However, it does not reach the lungs until later. The surfactant appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

Clinically this condition presents immediately after birth and findings such as tachypnea, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, subcostal retractions, and cyanosis may be seen.

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase the production of surfactants in premature infants.

Maddox Rod Test

  • It involves the use of a Maddox rod and the Maddox tangent scale.
  • It uses a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image.
  • A patient is asked to fix on a point light 6 meters away.
  • The optical properties of the cylinders cause the streak of light to be situated 90° to the orientation of the parallel cylinders.
  • Because fusion is precluded by the Maddox rod, heterophorias, and heterotopias cannot be differentiated.
  • The Maddox rod can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.

Interpretation of the Test:

  • To test for horizontal deviations, the Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye (for this example, the left eye) with the cylinders in the horizontal direction.
  • The patient fixates a point source of light and then sees a vertical line with the left eye and white light with the right eye.
  • If the light superimposes the line, orthophoria is present.
  • In this example, as the light is on the left side of the line, it is an exodeviation; and if the light was on the right side of the line, an esodeviation would be present.

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted mainly on prolactin and growth hormone.

  • Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of starry sky appearance point towards a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma.

The biopsy image shows tumor cells with multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and high mitotic index closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (the "sky"). These cells have a high turnover rate. The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debr is, they are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris ( the "stars"). This produces a starry sky appearance, which is classical to Burkitt lymphoma. 

Burkitt lymphoma:

  • Most common NHL in children <15 years
  • Associated with translocation of MYC gene of chromosome 8 (Option A)
  • Translocations: t (8;14), t (2;8), t (8,22)
  • Three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic: affects children in Africa, affects the jaw, and maxilla and is EBV-associated (Option B)
    • Sporadic: in adults in Western countries 
    • Immunodeficiency associated: HIV infection
  • It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumour, Ki-67 stains 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67)

Histology: Starry sky pattern

Immunophenotype: 

  • The tumour cells express
    • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
    • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
    • Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
    • HLA-DR and CD43.
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumours.
    • Endemic BL are EBV positive, express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL in non-immunosuppressed patients are EBV negative and lack CD21 expression.

questions.text: A tourist with a travel history to India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a tourist with abdominal pain, and multiple episodes of diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is suggestive of the traveller’s diarrhea, most commonly caused by Enterotoxigenic E.Coli. The antidiarrheal agent used in the given scenario is loperamide. 

Loperamide is generally indicated in non-infective diarrhea, but it is also given as an anti-diarrheal agent in traveller's diarrhea in addition to antibiotics.

It is an opioid receptor agonist and slows intestinal motility by direct effects on the circular and longitudinal muscles. It reduces fecal volume and increases viscosity. It is used in traveller's diarrhea for symptomatic treatment in conjunction with antibiotics. It is avoided in patients with dysentery. 

Other options: 

Option A: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog effective in treating severe secretory diarrhea that occurs due to hormone-secreting tumors in the GIT and pancreas. Its use is limited in traveller's diarrhea. 

Option C: Rifaximin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of traveller's diarrhea. It is an alternative to Azithromycin due to poor absorption. 

Option D: Bismuth subsalicylate is an over-the-counter (OTC) preparation used as an antidiarrheal agent. It is used in the treatment of traveller's diarrhea but is not preferred over loperamide due to a requirement for large doses, and salicylate toxicity, especially in high-risk groups (pregnancy, children, and individuals who take aspirin).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Granisetron i+ dexamethasone+ aprepitant is used to treat Chemotherapy-induced Nausea and Vomiting(CINV).

The combination of 5-HT3 receptor antagonists, NK1 receptor antagonists, and dexamethasone has decreased emesis and decreased the use of rescue medications for patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy during the acute and delayed phases.

5-HT3 receptor antagonists- Drugs are ondansetron, granisetron, dolasetron, and palonosetron. These agents are believed to prevent CINV by antagonizing 5-HT3 receptors either peripherally on vagal nerve terminals and/or centrally in the chemoreceptor trigger zone. The most common adverse effects are headaches and constipation.

NK1 receptor antagonists- They inhibit substance P in peripheral and central emetic pathways. Aprepitant was the first drug in this class to be approved by the FDA. The most common adverse effects include fatigue, headache, anorexia, diarrhoea, and increased transaminases.

Corticosteroids- They are now considered a mainstay of antiemetic regimens for the prevention of acute and delayed emesis. Dexamethasone is the recommended corticosteroid according to current guidelines.

Dopamine receptor antagonists were the primary antiemetics used for CINV, before the approval of the 5-HT3 antagonists. They have serious extrapyramidal side effects like akathisia, dystonia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome. With the current availability of more effective preventive agents, dopamine receptor antagonists are mostly used in the management of breakthrough or refractory emesis.  This class includes prochlorperazine, haloperidol, droperidol, and metoclopramide.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of renal calculi complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Skeletal radiographic survey shows subperiosteal resorption of 2nd and 3rd metacarpals and phalanges. On investigation, serum calcium and PTH were raised and phosphate levels were decreased.  The most common cause of the given clinical condition is _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma arising sporadically. 

It is associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and mutations in both copies of the MEN1 gene.

Hyperparathyroidism is caused by elevated parathyroid hormone and is classified into primary, secondary, and tertiary types.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the most common endocrine disorders, and it is an important cause of hypercalcemia. Tumors of the parathyroid glands usually come to attention because of excessive secretion of PTH rather than mass effects.

The clinical manifestations of hyperparathyroidism can be summarized as “painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans.” Skeletal manifestations of hyperparathyroidism include bone resorption, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and brown tumors. Renal changes include nephrolithiasis (stones) and nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient presented with meningoencephalitis. Laboratory workup for Herpes Simplex is negative. An increased rate of deaths in crows in the neighborhood has been reported. You suspect an arbovirus whose life cycle is shown below. It can be classified under which of the following genus?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of West Nile encephalitis caused by the West Nile Virus belonging to the genus Flaviviridae. Other important species under the genus flavivirus include:

  • Dengue virus
  • Japanese encephalitis virus
  • Yellow fever virus

West Nile Virus is a common viral febrile illness and is the most common cause of arboviral encephalitis in the United States. It is also seen in The Middle East, Europe, Africa, and Asia. In India, it is found in regions of Rajasthan to Karnataka.

The virus has a predominantly enzootic lifecycle involving birds and mosquitos, mostly belonging to the Culex species such as C. pipiens (although Aedes and Anopheles might also be rarely involved). Humans and other mammals such as horses are incidentally involved in the cycle. Very rarely, the virus may be transmitted through organ transplantation and blood transfusion. 

Clinically, the majority of the West Nile Virus infections are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients present with fever, maculopapular rash, lymphadenopathy, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and fatigue. The elderly, ill, and immunocompromised individuals may be affected more severely than the general population. They may develop neurological manifestations such as tremors, acute flaccid paralysis resembling polio, aseptic meningitis, and diffuse encephalitis. Very rarely, patients may develop features of transient parkinsonism. 

Note:

Arbovirus is a term used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors. There is no family or order by the name arbovirus. The word arbovirus is an acronym (Arthropod-Borne virus).

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of a gunshot wound sustained while on a hunting trip. X-ray findings are as given below. Which of the following weapons is most likely to produce this type of injury?
questions.solution:
The radiograph is suggestive of a close-range shotgun blast injury to the knee. Birdshot pellets are visible within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

 

The image given below shows the entry wound in the case of a shotgun. There is a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole. This wound is most likely to have been caused by a shotgun from a range of 1-5 m.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is antral lavage not indicated?
questions.solution:
In acute maxillary sinusitis, antral lavage is actually contraindicated for the risk of osteomyelitis.

Antral lavage is usually done therapeutically to remove pus and diagnostically for confirmation of chronic maxillary sinusitis. It can also be done to collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

questions.text: As the medical superintendent of a hospital, you wish to optimise the utilization of health services. What bed turnover interval should you aim for?
questions.solution:
For optimum utilization of health services in a hospital, bed turnover interval must always be slightly positive.

Bed turnover interval is defined as the time interval where a hospital bed is left unoccupied following a patient’s discharge till the next patient occupies it after admission.

questions.text: Which of the following is a purine analog used in treating gout?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is the purine analog, used in the treatment of hyperuricemia and gout, which inhibits purine biosynthesis and xanthine oxidase activity.

Other options:

Option A: Cytarabine is a pyrimidine nucleoside analog which is an anticancer drug used in the treatment of leukemias.

Option C: Febuxostat is a recently introduced non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor, equally or more effective than allopurinol in lowering blood uric acid levels in patients with hyperuricemia and gout.

Option D: Capecitabine is a pyrimidine analog that is classified as an antimetabolite agent.

questions.text: Which is the new online software launched under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) by the government to monitor TB patients?
questions.solution:
NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB).

Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring TB patients to monitor the Revised National Tuberculosis Programme (RNTCP). This system stores information about the patient, medical history, diagnosis, co-morbidities and lab reports. 

The system has been developed jointly by the Central TB Division of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and National Informatics Centre (NIC) and it was launched by the Government of India in June 2012. This is used by health functionaries at various levels across the country in association with Central TB Division (CTD), Ministry of Health & Family Welfare.

NIKSHAY covers various aspects of controlling TB using technological innovations.

Apart from web-based technology, SMS services have been used effectively for communication with patients and monitoring the program on a day-to-day basis.

Other options:

Option B: Nikusth is the new online software for monitoring leprosy patients.

Option C: Nischay is a pregnancy test kit.

Option D: Axshya is a project that works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between the government and civil society.

questions.text: Using impedance audiometry, stapedial reflexes are being assessed in a child with cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following cranial nerves is being tested here?
questions.solution:
The 7th and 8th cranial nerves are being tested in a child by assessing the stapedial reflexes. 

The afferent of stapedial reflex is the 8th cranial nerve and efferent is the 7th cranial nerve.

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

questions.text: The following test was done on a patient with squint and the finding noted is shown. What is the defect seen in the left eye?
questions.solution:
The test shown is the cover - uncover test. There is abduction of the eye with suspected deviation (left eye) on covering the fixing eye (right eye) which suggests left esotropia.

This test consists of two parts:

  • Cover test
  • Uncover test

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotropia (manifest squint). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate on a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotropia/Heterotropia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria
Adduction (Nasal recovery) Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward/Upward movement Vertical phoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery is noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

questions.text: A new drug X is in the pipeline for the treatment of Guillain Barre syndrome. In which of the following phases is its efficacy and dose range first determined?
questions.solution:
Determination of efficacy and appropriate dose range is the main aim of phase 2 of clinical trials. It is conducted on a small group of patients with the target disease.

Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease. The study is designed to obtain proof of concept (Potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase 3 studies).

Phase 1 (first in humans) is carried out with 10-100 participants. It aims to test the safety and tolerability of the drug. Usually, healthy volunteers are chosen. Sometimes patients with advanced or rare diseases are also considered. It generally lasts for 1-2 years. 

Phase 2 (first in patients) checks the efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug. 50-500 patient subjects receive the experimental drug. It lasts for 2-3 years. 

Phase 3 (multisite trial) is carried out for confirmation of the efficacy tested in phase 2. The indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. A few hundred to a few thousand patient subjects receive the drug. It lasts for around 3-5 years.

Phase 4 (postmarketing surveillance) tests for adverse effects, or those that occur only after long-term use and drug interactions. It is done in patients already on treatment with the approved drug. There is no fixed duration for this stage.

Arsenic is an odorless, tasteless, metallic poison. Gastrointestinal features of acute arsenic poisoning include nausea and vomiting, colicky abdominal pain, and profuse diarrhea with rice water stools.

Renal manifestations include chronic nephritis and urine contains albumin, casts, etc. 

Arsenic can be detected in the bones for prolonged periods. Hence it can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body. Dimercaprol is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning.

questions.text: What is the effect of cholecystokinin on GIT?
questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying. 

It is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides, fatty acids, and amino acids.

Primary functions:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Contraction of the gallbladder
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

Other functions:

  • Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline (bicarbonate rich) pancreatic juice
  • Inhibition of gastric emptying
  • Trophic (growth) effect on the exocrine pancreas
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon
  • Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing the reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach
  • It promotes satiety

questions.text: A male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) was prescribed theophylline. He noticed that his urine output had increased the following day. This action of the drug is mediated through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
An increased urine output after administering theophylline is due to the antagonism at adenosine A1 receptors.

The adenosine A1 receptors are present in the afferent arteriole of the glomeruli. When activated, they cause vasoconstriction that reduces the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal blood flow. This reduces urine output. Antagonistic action on these receptors will cause an increased GFR and renal blood flow and hence increased urine output.

Methylxanthines like theophylline and aminophylline are the bronchodilators used mainly in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and bronchial asthma. The pharmacological actions of theophylline are:

  • It inhibits phosphodiesterase (PDE) non-selectively, thereby increasing cellular cAMP and cGMP, causing bronchodilation. 
  • Adenosine causes bronchoconstriction by releasing histamine and leukotrienes. Theophylline antagonizes adenosine A1 receptors and causes bronchodilation.
  • It increases IL-10 release, which has anti-inflammatory actions.
  • It causes a decrease in gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
  • It promotes apoptosis of granulocytes and thereby, reduces the inflammatory load in the airways.

Adverse effects of theophylline:

  • Headache, nausea, and vomiting (due to inhibition of PDE4)
  • Increased acid secretion (due to PDE inhibition)
  • Diuresis (due to inhibition of adenosine A1 receptors)
  • Cardiac arrhythmias (due to inhibition of cardiac PDE3 and antagonism of cardiac A1 receptors).
  • Seizures (due to central A1 receptor antagonism).

Theophylline is mainly metabolized mainly by the enzyme CYP1A2. Therefore, it has various drug interactions, which include:

  1. Agents that lower its plasma level are smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, and phenobarbitone.
  2. Drugs that increase its plasma level are erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, oral contraceptives, and allopurinol.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with fever, sore throat, polyarthralgia, erythema marginatum, and chest pain. A rapid streptococcal antigen is found to be positive. Physical examination is remarkable for a loud friction rub. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. Serous pericarditis is seen in acute rheumatic fever.

Serous pericarditis is associated with conditions such as rheumatic fever, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), systemic scleroderma, tumors, uremia, viral infections, or tuberculosis. It involves mild inflammation of the epicardial and pericardial surfaces, characterized by both acute and chronic inflammatory cells. The condition leads to the exudation of serous fluid, typically ranging from 50 to 200 mL, which develops slowly and rarely affects cardiac function.

Other options:

Option A: Suppurative (purulent) pericarditis caused by bacterial, mycotic, or parasitic invasion of the pericardial space. The infection can spread through direct extension, blood seeding, lymphatic spread, or instrumentation. This form of pericarditis may extend into the surrounding mediastinum and typically results in the formation of adhesions, leading to constrictive pericarditis with significant clinical consequences.

Option C: Hemorrhagic pericarditis is most commonly seen in cases of tuberculosis or malignant neoplasms, particularly from the lung or breast, and can also occur after cardiac surgery.

Option D: Caseous pericarditis is almost always tubercular in origin.

questions.text: Which of the following fungi shows the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows germ tube formation (also known as the Reynolds Braude phenomenon), which is seen in Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C.

It is also positive for a relatively new characterized species, Candida dubliniensis.

It is negative in Candida glabrata.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

questions.solution:
Beta 1-3 glucan assay test is used to diagnose Pneumocystis jiroveci.

questions.text: Identify the defect shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows the congenital defect of anencephaly.

Failure of the cranial end of the neural tube to close is known as exencephaly. As a result of this, the skull vault does not form. This leaves the malformed brain exposed.

The exposed brain tissue degenerates, leaving a mass of necrotic tissue. This defect with the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is known as anencephaly. The brain stem remains intact.

In some cases, the closure defect of the neural tube extends caudally, and the spinal cord is affected. This condition is known as craniorachischisis, where there is anencephaly plus a large defect involving the spine.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium in the urinary bladder.

The deepest layer has columnar cells, the middle layers are made up of polyhedral cells and the surface layer has cells that are large and shaped like an umbrella.

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and part of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called urothelium. In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: During triaging of casualties from a building collapse, you find a patient who is able to walk but has sprained his ankle along with abrasions on the legs. You would classify him under:
questions.solution:
This patient can be triaged under the color green. In triage, green signifies low-priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

Triage consists of rapidly categorizing injured patients based on the severity of their illness and the likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention.

The most common internationally accepted triage system is the  four-color code system:

  • Red: High-priority treatment or transfer
  • Yellow: Medium priority
  • Green: Ambulatory patients
  • Black: Moribund or dead patients

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of :
questions.solution:
The middle radioulnar joint is a type of fibrous joint called syndesmosis.

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

  • The oblique cord - extends from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity to the radius, distal to the radial tuberosity.
  • Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types:

1. Fibrous
  • Sutures - Peculiar to the skull. (Eg:joints between skull bones)
  • Syndesmoses - There is a true fibrous connection between bones. ( Eg: distal tibiofibular joint, middle radioulnar join )
  • Gomphose - A peg sits inside a socket supported by fibrous connections. (Eg: joint between teeth and teeth sockets in mandibular/maxillary bone)

2. Cartilaginous

  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous (Eg:costochondral joints)
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous (Eg:manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints)

3. Synovial

  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient on oral contraceptives presented with abdominal pain and increasing abdominal girth for the past five days. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and ascites. A liver biopsy showed severe centrilobular congestion and necrosis and organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of hepatic vein thrombosis or Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Obstruction of the major hepatic veins due to thrombosis leads to a condition known as Budd-Chiari syndrome. It presents with a triad of abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The damage to the hepatic tissue is a result of increased intrahepatic blood pressure. It principally affects young women with an underlying hypercoagulable state such as deficiency of protein C, S, or anti-thrombin. Oral contraceptive intake increases the risk of hepatic vein thrombosis. Hepatic vein thrombosis is also associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms like polycythemia vera, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Grossly the liver is swollen, red-purple in color and has a tense capsule. Microscopically, there may be areas of hemorrhage alternating with areas of preserved parenchyma. Centrilobular congestion and necrosis is seen. The major hepatic veins contain thrombi and they may get organized into the wall of the vessel.

Other options:

Option B: Metastatic liver disease - It typically presents with multiple liver lesions and is not associated with centrilobular congestion, organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins, or the clinical picture described in the scenario. 

Option C: Primary biliary cholangitis, previously called primary biliary cirrhosis, is an autoimmune disease associated with inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It usually presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. 

Option D: Secondary biliary cirrhosis refers to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring, secondary to chronic obstruction of the extrahepatic bile ducts.

  • Part of this stimulation of alveolar ventilation results from direct stimulation of the respiratory centre by nervous signals. An additional part is believed to result from sensory signals transmitted into the respiratory centre from the contracting muscles and joint proprioceptors.

questions.text: During a pandemic of influenza a drug that inhibits the elution process of the virus was used. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Oseltamivir is a viral neuraminidase inhibitor that inhibits the elution process of the virus.

Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell surface. This occurs due to neuraminidase (NA) which is present on the surface of the influenza virus. (Influenza contains two surface antigens HA and NA). Neuraminidase destroys the receptor which is used for binding. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE). Oseltamivir inhibits neuraminidase activity and leads to viral aggregation at the cell surface and reduced virus spread within the respiratory epithelium. 

Options A and D: Interference with the M2 protein of influenza virus is seen with amantadine and rimantadine.

Option C: The endonuclease inhibitor for the treatment of acute uncomplicated influenza in adults is baloxavir marboxil.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen shows sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:

Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site is in the gastrointestinal tract or breast. It is often bilateral. Primary sites include the stomach (70%); carcinoma of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma). Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Signet ring cells are mucin-producing cells with the appearance of a signet ring often originating from the gastric mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about visceral pain?

choices.text: It is mediated by B fibers

questions.solution:

It often radiates (or is referred) to other somatic structures perhaps due to convergence of somatic and visceral nociceptive afferent fibers on the same second-order neurons in the spinal dorsal horn that project to the thalamus and then to the primary somatosensory cortex.

When pain is referred, it is usually to a structure that developed from the same embryonic segment or dermatome as the structure in which the pain originates. This principle is called the dermatomal rule.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest shows bilateral wheeze. The image of a characteristic finding in the sputum is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological image showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest field defect observed in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
A relative paracentral scotoma is the earliest clinically significant field defect observed in glaucoma.

The pattern of visual field progression in glaucoma from early to severe is predictable in light of the pattern of thinning of the retinal nerve fiber layer, which usually begins with the superior and inferior arcuate fibers, then the papillomacular bundle and, and finally the nasal fibers. Since the nasal fibers are the last to be involved, the temporal field is the last to be affected in glaucoma.

questions.text: A mutation in which section of DNA could influence the binding of RNA polymerase to the DNA?
questions.solution:
A mutation in the Promoter section of DNA could influence the binding of RNA polymerase to the DNA.

The regulatory portion of the operon is upstream of the three structural genes, and consists of the following:

  • The promoter (P) region where RNA polymerase binds
  • Two additional sites, the operator (O) site, and the CAP site, where regulatory proteins bind

Note: A lack of Corepressor would result in the inability of the cell to ʺturn offʺ genes.

Corepressor is a substance that inhibits the expression of genes. In prokaryotes, corepressors are small molecules whereas, in eukaryotes, corepressors are proteins.

A corepressor binds to the repressors and activates the repressor transcription factor, and the repressor, in turn, binds to the operator site, thereby blocking the transcription from the structural genes.

Sometimes an accessory pancreatic duct is present, and opens into the minor duodenal papilla. It is about 2 cm proximal to the major duodenal papilla in the second part of the duodenum.

  • Duodenal villous adenomas are commonly found around the ampulla of Vater and they are premalignant.
  • Duodenal injuries with tissue loss distal to the major duodenal papilla and proximal to the superior mesenteric vessels are best treated by Roux-en-Y duodenojejunostomy.

questions.text: Hyperosmolarity of renal medulla is due to____
questions.solution:
Hyperosmolarity of the medullary interstitium is mainly due to NaCl and urea.

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are 

  • Active transport of Na+ and co-transport of K+, Cl-, and other ions out of the thick portion of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the medullary interstitium.
  • Active transport of ions from the collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Facilitated diffusion of urea from the inner medullary collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium.
  • Diffusion of only small amounts of water from the medullary tubules into the medullary interstitium

questions.text: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is _____
questions.solution:
The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is Angiotensin II.

Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance and decreases Na+ and H2O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man experiences severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. He was admitted to the emergency ward. ECG showed ST segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbed after 3 hours.  During autopsy heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride  solution. What will be the colour imparted to the viable myocardium?
questions.solution:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain imparts a brick red colour to the intact non-infarcted myocardium.

  • Myocardial infarcts less than 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyltetrazolium chloride.
  • This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, noninfarcted myocardium where lactate dehydrogenase activity is preserved.
  • Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in the mandibular left posterior region since 2 months. The swelling was initially small and quickly increased in size. Incisional biopsy was done, and histopathological analysis of the hematoxylin/eosin-stained material showed sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stain positive for desmin and Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The tumour is most likely an embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma: Malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation
  • Three subtypes: alveolar (20%), embryonal (60%), and pleomorphic (20%).
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma (alveolar and embryonal): Most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood and adolescence.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.
  • The pediatric forms often arise in the sinuses, head and neck, and genitourinary tract.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma frequently contains fusions of the FOXO1 gene to either the PAX3 or the PAX7 gene, rearrangements marked by the presence of (2;13) or(1;13) translocations, respectively.
  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Rhabdomyoblasts with visible cross-striations may be present.
  • Sarcoma botryoids: variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina with cambium layer.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - Large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells
  • Immunohistochemistry: Positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin
  • The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.

questions.text: The given image shows the synthesis and release of GABA in the nerve terminal. Identify the drug that acts at site A.
questions.solution:
The drug that acts at the site 'A' is baclofen.

Baclofen is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. It is an analog of the inhibitory transmitter GABA and acts as a selective GABAB receptor agonist. It also acts at the spinal cord where it decreases excitatory transmitter release of excitatory neurotransmitter release.

Baclofen is used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal injuries, and flexor spasm. In these conditions, baclofen is the preferred drug for symptomatic relief.

It can also be administered intrathecally around the spinal cord through a catheter placed surgically. Side effects of baclofen include drowsiness, mental confusion, weakness, and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Benzodiazepines are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor that bind at the α/γ interface of the receptor. This increases the affinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA thus increasing the frequency of the opening of the chloride channel. They are selective CNS depressants that produce sedation, relieve anxiety, facilitate sleep, suppress seizures, and reduce muscle tone.

Option B: Tiagabine inhibits the GABA transporter GAT-1 and thereby reduces GABA uptake into neurons and glia and prolongs the action of GABA in the synapse. It is also used as an adjunct therapy for partial seizures with or without secondary generalization.

Option D: Gabapentin is an anti-epileptic drug that acts by binding to α2δ protein. It is used in focal onset seizures, neuropathic pains like post-herpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain. The most common adverse effects seen with gabapentin are increased drowsiness, ataxia, and fatigue.

questions.text: A female patient presented with painful swelling and watering in her left eye for a few weeks. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following treatment is not preferred for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of painful swelling and watering of eyes along with the image showing a reddish swelling in the lid with edema is suggestive of hordeolum externum or stye. Intralesional injection of triamcinolone is not effective in its management. Instead, triamcinolone injections are used for the treatment of chalazion, injected directly into and around the lesion.

Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland or Moll gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with systemic antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done. 

A chalazion is a sterile chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland due to retained sebaceous secretion. It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst. Complete spontaneous resolution occurs rarely. Oral antibiotics are only required for lesions with significant bacterial infections. Daily hot compression can help in the resolution of early lesions. Treatment includes incision and curettage, which is conventional and effective. Intralesional injection of steroid into and around the lesions give a similar resolution to incision and curettage.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic picture of both tympanic membranes exhibits a reddish blush, known as Schwartz sign, due to increased vascularity. This finding, combined with a history of bilateral conductive hearing loss, is indicative of active otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause. Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis Willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

On examination, Schwartz sign/flamingo flush showing a red blush of the tympanic membrane can be seen. This appearance is due to hypervascularization in the region of the cochlear promontory, which occurs in the active phase of otosclerosis as new blood vessels form around the focus of bone remodelling.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to speed up the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is surgical management which includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Hearing aids are used in patients who refuse or are unfit for the surgery.

The image shown below shows Carhart's notch.

Other options:

Option A: A rising sun sign is seen in the glomus tumour.

Option C: The setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus.

Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.
