questions.text: A corpse is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of death in a case where the ligature is completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid, with no saliva dribbling, is ligature strangulation.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark, which is transverse and completely encircles the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Ligature and manual strangulations are mostly homicidal. Marks of violence are usually seen on other parts of the body.

Other options:

Option A: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck.

Option C: Gagging is a type of asphyxia due to forcible closure of the mouth by a cloth or closing the mouth and nose and is tied around the head. 

Option D: Hanging is characterized by an incomplete and oblique ligature mark on the neck. It is usually seen higher, between the chin and larynx. Saliva often dribbles from the mouth.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in Samter's triad?

Acute asthma attacks usually occur 3 hours after intake of aspirin or NSAIDs. Severe rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

questions.text: A research study is being conducted on patients in rehabilitation where the impact of addiction among young adults was assessed on their subsequent divorce. questions.solution:
The above study design is typical of a case-control study. Here the divorced group acts as a case study group while the non-divorced group acts as a control.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: Which of the following protocols set the standard to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases internationally?
questions.solution:
The Kyoto Protocol was an internal agreement to set internationally binding emission reduction targets.

It is linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18% in the period between 2013-2020.

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

  • Certain gases in the atmosphere absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after it has left the Earth’s surface
  • These gases are known as greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs)
  • These gases then emit longwave radiation in all directions, the downward going portion of which add to the radiation arriving at the Earth’s surface and raise the equilibrium temperature.
  • In this entire process, the Earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as Greenhouse effect.
  • The most important natural GHGs are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, tropospheric ozone and nitrous oxide and non-natural GHGs are chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
  • Stratospheric ozone is not harmful and doesn’t contribute to the greenhouse effect
  • Greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.
  • The Kyoto Protocol is an internal agreement linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change by which its Parties set internationally binding emission reduction targets. The Parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18 percent in period between 2013 and 2020.
  • The Paris Agreement central aim is to strengthen the global response to the threat of climate change by keeping a global temperature rise this century well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius. It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, apdaptation and finance starting in the year 2020.

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Such questions are permitted during which of the following?
questions.solution:
Leading questions are not allowed in all of the given options except cross-examination, i.e leading questions are allowed during cross-examination.

As per section 141 of the Indian Evidence Act, a leading question is one which is suggestive of the answer that is desired or one which includes a fact and leads to the admitting of a conclusive answer, such as yes or no.

Cross-examination is one wherein the witness is questioned by the opposite party's lawyer, i.e the lawyer for the accused or the defense lawyer. It is undertaken with the objective to demonstrate favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and to discredit the witness.

The sequence of examination while recording evidence is as follows:

  1. Examination-in-Chief/direct examination by the party that summoned the witness to elicit all the facts from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed (option C). The only exception is if the judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile. 
  2. Cross-examination is done by the defence lawyer.
  3. Re-examination is done by the party that summoned the witness to correct or clarify or detail the statements made by the witness during cross-examination. Leading questions are not allowed (option A).

Other options:

Option D: A dying declaration is an oral or written statement made by a person who is dying. The doctor should certify that the person is conscious and with normal mental faculties before the declaration is recorded. It is recorded by the executive magistrate, or a doctor in the presence of two witnesses, if there is no time for the magistrate to come. Leading questions should not be asked.

questions.text: A man is brought to the casualty with swelling after sustaining a bee sting over his face. Which of the following vascular changes is not observed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Bee stings result in acute inflammation at the site of the sting. In this condition, there is decreased oncotic pressure due to protein leakage.

There is a release of inflammatory mediators like histamine which result in the following vascular changes: 

  • Vasodilation - results in erythema and stasis of blood flow
  • Increased vascular permeability -
    • Due to mediators like histamine, kinins, or endothelial injury (direct or leukocyte-induced ), or transcytosis
    • Results in leakage of proteins (reduced vascular oncotic pressure) and leukocyte migration 
  • Increased hydrostatic pressure - results in fluid leakage from blood vessels resulting in edema

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resemble the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness, followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The image below shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis:

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment of the infection includes 4 steps:

  1. Initiation of therapy (amphotericin B) as early as possible. Posaconazole can also be used in the management of this condition.
  2. Surgical debridement
  3. Reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors
  4. Treatment of underlying malignancy if present.

The image below shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of a black or greyish membranes in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: The IL-1 receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is _________
questions.solution:
The IL-1 receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is anakinra.

It is a biological Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drug (DMARD) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. All biological DMARDs downregulate the immune system and can lead to adverse effects like opportunistic infections and flaring of latent TB.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

NSAIDs - Analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive agents for the management of uncontrollable symptoms and useful in an acute flare.

Glucocorticoids - Used during an acute flare for rapid disease control and as initial therapy before the onset of the effect of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed to control disease in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone- oral 
  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     
DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs

Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX): It is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: It used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine: A salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide: A pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

 

Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists: Used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept: A T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab: An anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra: An IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with an anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists: Tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

 

Small molecules: Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, barcitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A patient presented with bull neck edema and a pseudomembrane on the tonsils. All of the following stains can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules of this organism, except?
questions.solution:
Presence of bull neck edema and pseudomembrane on tonsils points towards Diptheriae. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. All of the given stains can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules of this organism, except Fontana’s stain. Fontana’s silver impregnation method is used for staining treponeme and leptospira.

Albert’s stain is one of the commonly used stains to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/ Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The two other stains used for this purpose are Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain. The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. questions.text: An intern decides to insert a central venous catheter through a femoral vein in a burns victim to administer IV fluids. However, while inserting the needle, he accidentally injures the structures lying in the femoral sheath. Which of the following is unlikely to get injured here?

questions.text: Given below is the histological slide demonstrating a renal pathology. Which of the following would be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, sometimes filled with casts, resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.

Chronic pyelonephritis is a disorder in which there is chronic tubulointerstitial inflammation and scarring of the calyces and pelvis. Patients have a silent onset or present with manifestations of acute recurrent pyelonephritis, such as back pain, fever, pyuria, and bacteriuria. The hallmark features include coarse, discrete, corticomedullary scars overlying dilated, blunted, or deformed calyces, and flattening of the papillae.

The microscopic changes involve predominantly tubules and interstitium. The tubules show atrophy and hypertrophy or dilation. Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). 

Other options:

Option A: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is characterized by renal tubular epithelial cell injury and necrosis, leading to acute kidney injury. Histopathology shows tubular dilation, loss of brush border, epithelial flattening, and granular casts in the lumen.

Option C: Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, presenting with massive proteinuria. Histopathology shows normal glomeruli under light microscopy, but electron microscopy reveals podocyte foot process effacement.

Option D: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) can affect multiple organs, with renal involvement (lupus nephritis) being common. Histopathology shows immune complex deposition, wire-loop lesions, and mesangial proliferation in the kidneys, with positive immunofluorescence for IgG, IgA, and C3.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with Down's syndrome presents with a 14mm horizontal diameter of the cornea. The cornea is clear and vision is normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A horizontal corneal diameter of 14 mm in a 4-year-old child is suggestive of a megalocornea.

Megalocornea is diagnosed when the horizontal corneal diameter is 12 mm or more (up to 2 years of age) or 13 mm or more (if age >2 years). There is typically high myopia and astigmatism, but normal corrected visual acuity. Usually X-linked recessive; 90% of affected individuals are male.

Option A: Keratoglobus is a familial disorder, marked by thinning and hemispherical protrusion of the entire cornea. It can be congenital or acquired. A globular protrusion is seen here, in contrast to the conical ectasia seen in keratoconus. Intrastromal ring segments and cross-linking can be used for management.

Option B: Buphthalmos is a large eye that results from stretching due to raised IOP. The thin sclera appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. Primary congenital glaucoma presents with buphthalmos. Lack of other concomitant features helps rule out buphthalmos.

Option D: Micro-cornea - Horizontal corneal diameter is less than 10 mm.

questions.text: The image below shows the dissection of the right side of the neck and the red arrow denotes the right subclavian artery. What is not true about the structure labeled as A?

choices.text: Arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve
The right side nerve is shorter than the left
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior
It is purely a motor nerve

questions.solution:
The structure labeled as A is the phrenic nerve and all of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except for option D as it is a mixed nerve (both sensory and motor nerve).

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium, and parietal serous pericardium.

 

The phrenic nerve is a mixed nerve derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami.

It is formed at the lateral border of the scalenus anterior. At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is separated by the scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

The right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left. The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening. The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm just anterior to the central tendon.

*Clinical note - The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain which usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess. It is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

  • Citrulline and ornithine are other important urea cycle intermediates.
  • Aspartate is condensed with citrulline to form argininosuccinate in the urea cycle(Aspartate is not an intermediate)
  • Acetylglutamate is a cofactor in the joining of carbon dioxide with ammonia to form carbamoyl phosphate at the beginning of the urea cycle.

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. There is an accumulation of the precursors of urea - ammonia, and glutamine. They include:

  • Defect in carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I - Hyperammonemia type 1
  • Defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase - Hyperammonemia type 2
  • Defect in argininosuccinate synthetase - Citrullinemia
  • Defect in argininosuccinate lyase- Argininosuccinic aciduria
  • Defect in the gene for arginase- Hyperargininemia

questions.text: While conducting animal studies, a scientist is experimenting with a drug called vesamicol that causes skeletal muscle relaxation. What is the mechanism by which the drug causes muscle relaxation?

choices.text: Breakdown of acetylcholine after its release into the synaptic cleft
Blocks the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle
Inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals
Prevents the release of  acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.solution:
Vesamicol causes skeletal muscle relaxation by blocking the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle.

It acts on the cholinergic nerve terminals and blocks the transport, thus preventing the repletion of acetylcholinesterase following transmitter release. 

Other options:

Option A: Acetylcholine esterase is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine after it is released into the synaptic cleft to acetate and choline.

Option C: Hemicholinum inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals.

Option D: Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.
